title: Namespaces (Organizing Your Blueprints)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine a huge library with 100,000 books all mixed together on one shelf! Finding 'The Great Gatsby' would be impossible. Instead, libraries organize books:
• Fiction → Mystery → Author Name
• Non-Fiction → Science → Biology

That's what NAMESPACES do for code! They're FOLDERS for organizing classes:
• System.Collections.Generic → List, Dictionary
• System.IO → File, Directory
• YourApp.Models → Customer, Product
• YourApp.Services → EmailService, PaymentService

Namespaces prevent NAMING CONFLICTS: Microsoft can have 'Microsoft.UI.Button' and you can have 'MyApp.CustomControls.Button' - different namespaces, no conflict!

Think: namespace = 'The organizational folder path for your code.' Without namespaces, large projects become chaos!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Namespace wraps your classes. Use PascalCase. Dot notation for hierarchy: Company.Product.Feature (like folder paths!).
'using' at top of file imports a namespace. Now you can use classes from that namespace without full path. Like 'import' in other languages.
Full path to a class: 'System.Collections.Generic.List<int>'. Using statements let you skip the path: just 'List<int>'.
Convention: YourApp.Models (data classes), YourApp.Services (business logic), YourApp.Views (UI). Organize by feature or layer!

challenge.instructions:
Create a multi-namespace project structure!

1. NAMESPACE 'MyStore.Models':
   - Class Product: string Name, decimal Price

2. NAMESPACE 'MyStore.Services':
   - Class ShoppingCart:
     - List<Product> Items
     - Method AddItem(Product p): adds to Items, prints confirmation
     - Method GetTotal(): returns sum of all item prices

3. NAMESPACE 'MyStore':
   - Import both namespaces with 'using'
   - Create products
   - Create cart, add products
   - Display total
challenge.hint: Define namespaces: 'namespace Name { class C { } }'. Import: 'using Name;' at top of file. Nested namespaces use dots: Company.Product.Feature.
commonStickingPoints: Circular using statements: If namespace A uses B, and B uses A, you can get confusing errors! Organize code so dependencies flow one direction (Models → Services → UI).
Forgetting using in nested namespaces: If MyStore.Services needs Product from MyStore.Models, you must add 'using MyStore.Models;' INSIDE the Services namespace block!
Namespace doesn't match folder: By convention, namespace should match folder structure! File at 'MyApp/Models/Customer.cs' should have 'namespace MyApp.Models'. Not required, but strong convention.
Using vs namespace: 'using System;' IMPORTS a namespace (at top of file). 'namespace MyApp { }' DEFINES a namespace (wraps your code). Don't confuse them!
